\section{Generation of MIT 6.042: Mathematics for Computer Science}
\label{sec:generation-6.042}

\begin{longtable}{|l|p{8cm}|p{8cm}|}
\caption{New questions generated from 6.042 Mathematics for Computer Science dataset, and the closest question among the existing questions.}\\
\hline
\textbf{ID} & \textbf{Auto-Generated question} & \textbf{Closest question in the dataset}\\
\hline
1 & A fair coin is tossed until the first head appears. What is the expected number of tosses?   & 
MIT students sometimes delay laundry for a few days. Assume all random values described below are mutually independent. A relaxed student rolls a fair, 6-sided die in the morning. If he rolls a 1, then he does his laundry immediately (with zero days of delay). Otherwise, he delays for one day and repeats the experiment the following morning. Let R be the number of days a relaxed student delays laundry. What is Ex (R)? 

\\
\hline
2 & Suppose that a graph G is a tree. Prove that G is a DAG.   & 
Give a minimal example of a graph in which every vertex is adjacent to at least one other vertex, but the graph is not connected.

\\
\hline
3 & A student is taking a test consisting of n multiple-choice questions. Each question has five possible answers, and only one of them is correct. The student knows that the probability that any particular question is answered correctly is 1/5. Let X be the number of questions answered correctly by the student. What is E(X)?   & 
MIT students sometimes delay laundry for a few days. Assume all random values described below are mutually independent. A busy student must complete 3 problem sets before doing laundry. Each problem set requires 1 day with probability 2/3 and 2 days with probability 1/3. Let B be the number of days a busy student delays laundry. What is Ex (B)?


\\
\hline
4 & Suppose that you roll five 6-sided dice that are fair and mutually independent. What is the probability that all five dice show the same value? 
& 
Suppose that you roll five 6-sided dice that are fair and mutually independent. What is the probability that all five dice show different values?

\\ 
\hline
5 & Find a number $x \in \{0, 1, . . . , 101\}$ such that $11x \equiv 1 (\mod 102)$. & 
Find the multiplicative inverse of $17$ modulo $72$ in the range $\{0, 1, . . . , 71\}$.

\\
\hline
6 & Define a bijection between N and N × N × N (the ordered triples $(0,0,0),(0,0,1),(0,1,2)$,. . . of natural numbers). &
Define a bijection between N and N × N (the ordered pairs $(0,0),(0,1),(1,2)$,. . . of natural numbers).

\\
\hline
7 & Outside of their humdrum duties as 6.042 TAs, Sayan is trying to learn to levitate using only intense concentration and Jelani is launching a “Nelson 2008” presidential campaign. Suppose that Sayan’s probability of levitating is 1/6, Jelani’s chance of becoming president is 1/4, and the success of one does not alter the other’s chances. If neither of them succeeds, what is the probability that both of them learn to levitate? & 
Outside of their humdrum duties as 6.042 TAs, Sayan is trying to learn to levitate using only intense concentration and Jelani is launching a “Nelson 2008” presidential campaign. Suppose that Sayan’s probability of levitating is 1/6, Jelani’s chance of becoming president is 1/4, and the success of one does not alter the other’s chances. If at least one of them succeeds, what is the probability that Sayan learns to levitate?

\\
\hline
8 & Give a small example of a DAG with more than one maximum flow. & 
Give a small example of a DAG with more than one minimum time schedule.

\\
\hline
9 & Two identical complete decks of cards, each with 52 cards, have been mixed together. A hand of 5 cards is picked uniformly at random from amongst all subsets of exactly 5 cards. What is the probability that the hand has exactly two pairs of identical cards?   & 
Two identical complete decks of cards, each with 52 cards, have been mixed together. A hand of 5 cards is picked uniformly at random from amongst all subsets of exactly 5 cards. What is the probability that the hand has exactly one pair of identical cards?

\\
\hline
10 & How many ways are there to place n queens on an $n \times n$ chessboard so that no two queens are on the same row? & 
An electronic toy displays a $4 \times 4$ grid of colored squares. At all times, four are red, four are green, four are blue, and four are yellow. How many such configurations are possible? 

\\ \hline
\end{longtable}
title: A Neural Network Solves, Explains, and Generates University Math Problems by Program Synthesis and Few-Shot Learning at Human Level
